DOCNAME: CASE OF ZENTSOV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Degrading treatment;Inhuman treatment) (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-3 - Length of pre-trial detention)
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Erik Møse;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The second applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The third applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE Region .
CARDINAL . The applicants are members of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE a group of CARDINAL members of ORG occupied the waiting area of the President ’s administration building in GPE and locked themselves in an office on the ground floor .

CARDINAL . They asked for a meeting with the President , the deputy head of the President ’s administration and the President ’s economic adviser . They handed out leaflets through the windows featuring a printed letter to the President which listed CARDINAL ways in which he had allegedly failed to comply with the LAW and which called for his resignation .
CARDINAL . The intruders stayed in the office for TIME until the police broke down the locked door and arrested them . They did not offer any resistance to the authorities .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE ordered the applicants’ detention on the ground that they were suspected of an especially serious criminal offence .

CARDINAL . The applicants were charged , on DATE , with the attempted violent overthrow of ORG power ( LAW ) and the intentional destruction and degradation of others’ property in public places ( Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . By separate decisions of CARDINAL , DATE and DATE the ORG of GPE extended the applicants’ detention until DATE on the basis of the gravity of the charges . The court also found that the second applicant had no registered place of residence in GPE or the GPE region , and therefore there was a possibility that she might abscond or interfere with the investigation . In respect of the third applicant the court held that his permanent place of residence in the GPE region , ongoing studies at a university in GPE , previously clean criminal record and good character references were insufficient to warrant his release , given the gravity of the charges laid against him .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants’ charge was amended to that of participation in mass disorder , an offence under LAW .
CARDINAL . By separate but identically worded decisions of DATE ORG granted the prosecution ’s request for an extension of the applicants’ detention until DATE , for the following reasons :

“ The court takes into account that the case involves CARDINAL defendants who have just started , together with their counsel , to study the case file which comprises CARDINAL volumes ... Moreover , the prosecution needs additional time in order to prepare the bill of indictment ...

Having regard to the fact that [ the first and the second applicants ] are not registered with a permanent place of residence in GPE or the GPE region and taking into account the gravity of the charges and the prosecutor ’s arguments that [ the applicants ] , once released , might flee from justice , the court considers that [ the applicants ] should remain in custody . ”

CARDINAL . On appeal , counsel for the applicants asked for their release as they had no previous criminal record , had good character references and a permanent place of residence and were in employment or studying at the university . He further submitted that the applicants did not require much time to study the case file . At the appeal hearing before ORG the applicants confirmed that they had finished studying the case file .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the decisions of DATE , finding that they had been lawful , sufficiently reasoned and justified .
CARDINAL . The investigation was completed on DATE and CARDINAL persons , including the applicants , were committed for trial .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE scheduled the preliminary hearing for DATE and held that all the defendants should meanwhile remain in custody .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a preliminary hearing . It rejected the GPE requests for release , taking into account their character , young age , frail health , family situation and stable way of life . However , it found , referring to the gravity of the charges , that “ the grounds on which the preventive measure [ had been ] previously imposed still persist[ed ] ” and that “ the case file gave sufficient reasons to believe that , once released , the defendants would flee or interfere with the trial ” . It therefore ordered that all the defendants should remain in custody pending trial .
CARDINAL . The applicants lodged applications for release . On DATE ORG rejected these requests , finding that their detention was lawful and justified .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants filed new applications for release . On DATE ORG rejected the requests . It held :
“ The court takes into account the defence ’s argument that an individual approach to each defendant ’s situation is essential when deciding on the preventive measure .

Examining the grounds on which ... the court ordered and extended the detention of all the defendants without exception ... the court notes that these grounds still persist DATE . Therefore , having regard to the state of health , family situation , age , profession and character of all the defendants , and to the personal guarantees offered on their behalf by certain private individuals and included in the case file , the court concludes that , if released , each of the applicants might abscond or obstruct the course of justice in some other way ...
In the court ’s view , in these circumstances , having regard to the gravity of the charges , there are no grounds for varying or revoking the preventive measure in respect of any defendant ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found the applicants and their co - defendants guilty of participation in mass disorder . It gave each applicant a suspended sentence of DATE and released them all on probation .
CARDINAL . The first and third applicants were held in remand prison no . GPE in GPE .
CARDINAL . The Government provided the following description of the conditions of detention in respect of the first and third applicants .

CARDINAL . As regards the number of inmates sharing a cell with the first applicant , the Government relied on a number of excerpts from the prison population register in respect of DATE and the certificates prepared by the remand prison administration in DATE .

CARDINAL . As regards the number of inmates sharing a cell with the third applicant , the ORG relied on a number of excerpts from the prison population register in respect of DATE and the certificates prepared by the remand prison administration in DATE .
CARDINAL . According to the ORG , the first and third applicants were each provided with their own bed and bedding , a mug , a dish and a spoon .

CARDINAL . The lighting in the cells was in compliance with applicable standards . At TIME low - voltage bulbs were used to maintain lighting for surveillance purposes . The cells were serviced by a ventilation system in good working order . The inmates were allowed exercise for TIME per day in the prison yard . The cells were regularly disinfected .

CARDINAL . The first and third applicants contested the Government ’s submissions . According to them , the cells where they were detained were overcrowded at all times and infested with insects . The toilet had only been separated by a screen from the living area of the cell and did not offer any privacy . The applicants had been allowed to take a TIME shower once a week . The food was scarce and no medicine , other than aspirin and other analgesics , was available . The applicants had been permitted a walk for TIME . The exercise yard was sheltered and measured QUANTITY in area . No books or newspapers had been available .
